The definition of a(n) is the number of 2-matchings of the n X n grid graph. In graph theory, a k-matching is a set of k independent edges, meaning no two edges share a common vertex. Here, we specifically refer to 2-matchings, which are sets of 2 independent edges in the n X n grid graph.

category: *combinatorial mathematics, discrete mathematics, polynomial and series expansions*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is: Array T(m,n) read by antidiagonals: number of domino tilings (also known as dimer tilings) of an m x n grid (or m x n rectangle), where m, n >= 1. Consider T(m, n) being the number of ways to completely cover a grid of size m x n using 1 x 2 or 2 x 1 tiles.

category: *graph theory, combinatorial mathematics, geometry and topology*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the number of walks of length n along the edges of a regular dodecahedron between two opposite vertices, where a walk is defined as a sequence of moves between adjacent vertices of the polyhedron.

category: *graph theory, combinatorial mathematics, geometry and topology*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is: Closed walks of length n along the edges of a dodecahedron starting and ending at a vertex.
The definition of a(n) is the number of different strings of length n+5 obtained from the initial string "123...n" by iteratively duplicating any contiguous substring of the original string.
The definition of a(n) is the number of Dyck paths of length 2n using knight moves.
The definition of a(n) is the dimensions of the n-th multiple of the minimal representation of the complex Lie algebra E7.
The definition of a(n) is: The dimension of multiples of the minimal representation of the complex simple Lie algebra F4.
The definition of a(n) is: Dimensions (sorted, with duplicates removed) of finite-dimensional real simple Lie algebras.

category: *number theory, polynomial and series expansions, special numbers*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the n-th Fourier coefficient of the Eisenstein series E_10(q) (alternate convention E_5(q)) for the modular form with weight 10.
The definition of a(n) is the difference between the n-th triangular number t(n) and the square of the largest integer k such that k^2 is less than or equal to t(n).
The definition of a(n) is: 1 together with the sequence of positive even numbers.
The definition of a(n) is 1 together with nonnegative even numbers listed in increasing order.
The definition of a(n) is: Numbers such that the floor of the square of the number divided by 9 is a perfect square.
The definition of a(n) is the squares n^2 such that floor(n^2/9) is again a square number.

category: *combinatorial mathematics, special numbers, polynomial and series expansions*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the nth term of the sequence formed by reading the Triangle of Euler-Bernoulli, also known as Entringer numbers, by rows. Each entry in the triangle represents the number of permutations of a set with specific properties related to the alternating runs of the permutations.

The definition of a(n) is: If in a line of n persons every n-th person is eliminated until only one person is left, which position P should one assume in the original lineup to avoid being eliminated? P is the output for position n in the sequence.
The definition of a(n) is: Triangle T(n,m) = 1 + 2*m of odd numbers read along rows, 0 <= m < n.

The definition of a(n) is: If cards numbered 1 through n are "Down Two Table" shuffled (top two put on bottom one at a time, third from top card dealt to table) until all of the cards are placed on the table, a(n) is the number of the last card dealt.
The definition of a(n) is the number of positive integers \( k < n \) such that \( n \, \text{XOR} \, k < n \) and \( \text{gcd}(n, k) \) is odd.

The definition of a(n) is a variation of the Josephus problem, removing every other person in a circular arrangement, starting with person 1. The position a(n) refers to the last remaining person after repeatedly removing every second individual in this manner.

The definition of a(n) is: a(2n) = n, a(2n+1) = a(n). In this sequence, the term a(n) represents a value which can be derived from its indices based on whether the index is even or odd. For n >= 0, follow the rules provided to construct the sequence from the index.
The definition of a(n) is a linear version of the Josephus problem, where each position is taken modulo 12.

The definition of a(n) is the smallest number of stones in Tchoukaillon (or Mancala, or Kalahari) solitaire that make use of the n-th hole, where players distribute stones across holes on a board according to specific game rules common to Mancala variants.

The definition of a(n) is: Good sequence of increments for Shell sort (best on big values). This sequence provides an optimal set of gaps used in the Shell sort algorithm, which significantly improves the sorting efficiency, especially for larger datasets.

category: *discrete mathematics, combinatorial mathematics, polynomial and series expansions*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the number of comparisons needed for Batcher's odd-even mergesort algorithm when applied to sort 2^n items. This algorithm is a parallel comparison-based sorting algorithm that minimizes the number of comparisons.

category: *combinatorial mathematics, discrete mathematics, polynomial and series expansions*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the maximal number of comparisons needed for sorting n elements using the list merging technique.

category: *polynomial and series expansions, special numbers, discrete mathematics*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the expansion of the exponential generating function exp((exp(4*x) - 4 - 1)/4 + exp(x)) for p=4.

category: *graph theory, geometry and topology, discrete mathematics*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the genus of the complete graph on n nodes in graph theory, where genus is the minimum number of handles or "holes" required to embed the graph on a surface without edges crossing.
The definition of a(n) is: Arkons: number of elementary maps with n-1 nodes in the context of graph theory and cartographic map coloring.

category: *combinatorial mathematics, geometry and topology, discrete mathematics*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the number of unrooted nonseparable planar maps with n edges and a distinguished face.

category: *graph theory, combinatorial mathematics, geometry and topology*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the number of unrooted loopless planar maps with exactly n edges, where a planar map represents a connected graph embedded in the plane, and "loopless" means that no edge starts and ends at the same vertex.

The definition of a(n) is the number of distinct ways to map a set of n points to itself, where each mapping is considered identical under any permutation of the points; also known as the number of unlabeled endofunctions.

category: *graph theory, combinatorial mathematics, geometry and topology*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the number of tree-rooted bridgeless planar maps with exactly two vertices and n faces, where a planar map is a graph embedded in the plane such that no edges cross each other, and a map is bridgeless if there are no edges whose removal would increase the number of connected components. Additionally, a map is tree-rooted if it contains a designated spanning tree.

category: *combinatorial mathematics, discrete mathematics, polynomial and series expansions*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the number of n-step mappings of a set with 4 elements.

category: *combinatorial mathematics, geometry and topology, discrete mathematics*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the number of rooted toroidal maps with 2 faces and n vertices, where the maps do not contain separating cycles or isthmuses, ensuring that each map is connected and features a toroidal topology without discontinuities.

category: *combinatorial mathematics, geometry and topology, graph theory*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the number of nonseparable planar tree-rooted maps with n edges, where a tree-rooted map is a connected map (embedding of a graph on a plane) with a designated spanning tree. Nonseparable means that the map remains connected even if any single edge is removed.

category: *graph theory, geometry and topology, discrete mathematics*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the chromatic number (or Heawood number) of a nonorientable surface with n crosscaps, which is the minimum number of colors needed to color any map on a surface with n crosscaps such that no two adjacent regions have the same color.
The definition of a(n) is the number of rooted planar maps with a specified structure and constraints related to their edges and vertices in combinatorial graph theory.

category: *combinatorial mathematics, geometry and topology, graph theory*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the number of genus 0 rooted maps with 5 faces and n vertices, where a rooted map is a connected graph embedded in a plane such that any loop can be continuously transformed into a point within the plane, with a designated directed edge called the root.

The definition of a(n) is the number of nonseparable tree-rooted planar maps with n + 2 edges and 3 vertices, where planar maps are distinguished by their embedding in the plane and nonseparable means the map cannot be disconnected by removing a single vertex.
The definition of a(n) is the number of tree-rooted planar maps with 3 faces and n vertices, where no face is disconnected from the tree (i.e., no isthmuses are present).
The definition of a(n) is the number of ways to partition n into parts where each part is a prime number.
The definition of a(n) is: Numbers that cannot be expressed as the sum of two prime numbers.
The definition of a(n) is the largest prime number that is less than or equal to n and can be found in any decomposition of 2n as the sum of two odd prime numbers.

The definition of a(n) is: From the Goldbach problem: number of decompositions of 2n into unordered sums of two prime numbers, where a decomposition \( p + q \) (with \( p \leq q \)) is considered equivalent to \( q + p \).
The definition of a(n) is: Consider all pairs of primes (p,q) with p + q = 2n, p ≤ q; a(n) is the sum of all the q's.

The definition of a(n) is the number of directed graphs (tournaments) with n nodes that are uniquely determined by their score sequences, where the score sequence is the list of out-degrees of the nodes.

The definition of a(n) is the largest order of the automorphism group of a directed graph, called a tournament, with n nodes where each pair of nodes has a single directed edge between them in one direction or the other.

category: *polynomial and series expansions, special numbers, discrete mathematics*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is: Triangle of denominators in Leibniz's Harmonic Triangle a(n,k), where n >= 1, 1 <= k <= n, derived from the expansion of the harmonic series in a triangular form.
The definition of a(n) is the denominators of the harmonic numbers H(n) = Sum_{i=1..n} 1/i, where H(n) is expressed as a fraction in simplest form.
The definition of a(n) is the number of positive integers m for which the harmonic mean of m and n is a positive integer.
The definition of a(n) is the number of terms in the simple continued fraction for the n-th harmonic number \( H_n = \sum_{k=1}^n \frac{1}{k} \).

The definition of a(n) is the number of integer partitions of n whose smallest part is equal to the number of parts in the partition. For example, for n=4, the partitions are those where the smallest part of the partition equals the total number of parts in that partition.
The definition of a(n) is the number of ways to partition n into parts of the form 5k+2 or 5k+3, where k is a non-negative integer.
The definition of a(n) is the number of distinct partitions of n into parts such that if a part k appears, then k must also appear at least k times.

The definition of a(n) is the number of partitions of n in which each part occurs an odd number (or zero) times, where a partition of a number is a way of writing the number as a sum of integers, with order not mattering, and each part is an integer greater than zero that can appear multiple times in the sum.

category: *polynomial and series expansions, special numbers, combinatorial mathematics*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the EULER transform of the sequence 3, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, ...
The definition of a(n) is the number of sets of rooted connected graphs where every block is a complete graph, also known as k-trees, and each graph is uniquely rooted at a vertex.

category: *polynomial and series expansions, special numbers, number theory*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the coefficients in the expansion of \( q^{5/24} / (\eta(q) \eta(q^2)^2) \) in powers of \( q \), where \( \eta(q) \) is the Dedekind eta function.
The definition of a(n) is the number of partitions of n of the form a_1*b_1^2 + a_2*b_2^2 + ...; number of semisimple rings with p^n elements for any prime p.
The definition of a(n) is the number of partitions of n where there are two distinguishable types of 1's and two distinguishable types of 2's.

category: *number theory, polynomial and series expansions, special numbers*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is primes of the form 2x^2 + 2xy + 17y^2, where x and y are integers.
The definition of a(n) is e-perfect numbers: numbers k such that the sum of the e-divisors (exponential divisors, meaning the divisors d of k such that k = d^m for some integer m) of k equals 2*k.
The definition of a(n) is the number of ordered ways of writing n as the sum of 3 triangular numbers, where a triangular number is defined as T_k = k(k+1)/2 for some non-negative integer k.

category: *polynomial and series expansions, special numbers, number theory*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is: Factorial expansion of Gamma(1/4) = Sum_{n>=1} a(n)/n! with largest possible a(n), where Gamma is the Euler's gamma function.

category: *polynomial and series expansions, special numbers, number theory*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is: Factorial expansion of the natural logarithm of 2 given by the series Sum_{n>=1} a(n)/n!. Find the first n terms of the sequence.

category: *polynomial and series expansions, special numbers, number theory*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the coefficients in the harmonic expansion (or factorial expansion) of the Euler-Mascheroni constant γ.
The definition of a(n) is the number of digits in n! (n factorial) excluding any trailing zeros in its decimal representation.
The definition of a(n) is the result of dropping the final digit of n in its decimal representation. Each a(n) is an integer formed by removing the last digit from n.
The definition of a(n) is palindromes with an odd number of digits, where each digit in the palindrome reads the same forwards and backwards.

The definition of a(n) is the number of terms in the Farey sequence of order n, where the Farey sequence of order n is the set of completely reduced fractions between 0 and 1 which have denominators less than or equal to n, arranged in increasing order.

category: *number theory, special numbers, polynomial and series expansions*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the sum of odd Fermat coefficients rounded to the nearest integer.

category: *polynomial and series expansions, special numbers, discrete mathematics*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the expansion of the generating function (1 + x + 2*x^2)/((1 - x)^2*(1 - x^3)).
The definition of a(n) is the number of pairs (x,y) where 1 <= x, y <= n and gcd(x, y) = 1.

category: *polynomial and series expansions, special numbers, discrete mathematics*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the sequence derived from iterating the process x := x - (sin(x) - cos(x)*x - Pi/2)/(sin(x)*x) with a given initial value, representing the number of digits of the exact value of π, determining the decimal places in the calculations.
The definition of a(n) is the image of n under the map n -> n/2 if n is even, n -> 3n - 1 if n is odd.
The definition of a(n) is the number of times one must divide n by 2 to reach 1 in the context of the '3x+1' problem, also known as the Collatz conjecture, or -1 if this never happens.
The definition of a(n) is: Number of odd prime numbers encountered in the sequence generated by the 3x+1 (Collatz) problem starting from n.

category: *number theory, discrete mathematics, polynomial and series expansions*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the output image of n after one application of the "5x+1" transformation, which maps an integer n to 5n + 1.

The definition of a(n) is the largest k such that 2^k appears in the trajectory of the Collatz 3x+1 sequence started at n. The Collatz 3x+1 sequence is defined as follows: start with a positive integer n, and generate the next term by applying the rule: if the current term is even, divide it by 2; if it is odd, multiply it by 3 and add 1. Repeat this process with each subsequent term.
The definition of a(n) is the next odd term in the Collatz trajectory starting from n.

The definition of a(n) is the sequence defined by the following process: Start with any positive integer n. Then each term is obtained from the previous term as follows: if the previous term is even, the next term is one half of the previous term. If the previous term is odd, the next term is 3 times the previous term plus 1. Start the sequence at 15.

The definition of a(n) is: Sequence contains no 3-term arithmetic progression, other than its initial terms 1, 2, 3. The sequence is constructed such that after the terms 1, 2, 3, each additional term is chosen to avoid forming any new 3-term arithmetic progression with the previous terms.
The definition of a(n) is a(1)=1, a(2)=3; a(n) is the smallest integer k such that no three terms among a(1), a(2), ..., a(n-1), and k form an arithmetic progression.
The definition of a(n) is the number of perfect riffle shuffles required to return a deck of 2n cards to its original order.
The definition of a(n) is the least number m for which either 2^m + 1 or 2^m - 1 is divisible by 4n + 1, where n represents the number of pairs of cards in a Mongean shuffle.

The definition of a(n) is: Least gap in the partition having Heinz number n; index of the least prime not dividing n. Heinz number of a partition is the product of primes (2, 3, 5, ...) corresponding to parts of the partition.

category: *polynomial and series expansions, special numbers, discrete mathematics*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the coefficients of x^n in the Hermite polynomial H_{n+4}. Hermite polynomials H_n(x) are a classical orthogonal polynomial sequence that are used in probability, physics, and numerical analysis, defined by the recurrence relation H_{n+1}(x) = 2x H_n(x) - 2n H_{n-1}(x) with initial conditions H_0(x) = 1 and H_1(x) = 2x.

The definition of a(n) is: Square array of pyramidal numbers in three dimensions, read by antidiagonals. Note that pyramidal numbers, also known as square pyramidal numbers, represent sums of squares of natural numbers.
The definition of a(n) is the squares of odd pentagonal pyramidal numbers.
The definition of a(n) is the number of walks of length n between two vertices that are adjacent (distance 1) on an icosahedron.

category: *graph theory, combinatorial mathematics, geometry and topology*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the number of closed walks of length n along the edges of a regular icosahedron, starting and ending at the same vertex.

category: *polynomial and series expansions, special numbers, combinatorial mathematics*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the coefficient triangle of generalized Laguerre polynomials with parameter a=1.

category: *polynomial and series expansions, special numbers, combinatorial mathematics*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the coefficient triangle of generalized Laguerre polynomials n! * L(n,3,x) (using rising powers of x).

The definition of a(n) is the number of positive integers k which are <= n and where k, k-1 and k+1 are each coprime to n. For context, two numbers are considered coprime if their greatest common divisor (GCD) is 1.
The definition of a(n) is the number of prime numbers between n^2 and (n+1)^2, inclusive.

category: *combinatorial mathematics, number theory, polynomial and series expansions*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the number of solutions to the equation k_1 + 2*k_2 + ... + n*k_n = 0, where each k_i is an integer from the set {-1, 0, 1}, for i=1 to n.
The definition of a(n) is the number of letters in the Roman numeral representation of n.
The definition of a(n) is the parity (even or odd) of the number of prime factors of n, counted with multiplicity. If the number of prime factors is even, a(n) = 1; if odd, a(n) = 2.

The definition of a(n) is Dyck language interpreted as binary numbers in ascending order, where Dyck language consists of balanced strings of parentheses that can be translated into binary numbers by interpreting '(' as '1' and ')' as '0'.
The definition of a(n) is numbers whose digits contain no loops or closed curves (as appearing in the standard digital representation of digits).

category: *combinatorial mathematics, discrete mathematics, polynomial and series expansions*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the number of ways for \(n-3\) nonintersecting loops to cross a line \(2n\) times, considering each distinct configuration resulting from the loops as an arrangement where loops do not intersect and each passage of the loop across the line contributes to the count.

The definition of a(n) is: "Magic" integers: a(n+1) is the smallest integer m such that there is no overlap between the sets {m, m-a(i), m+a(i): 1 <= i <= n} and {a(i), a(i)-a(j), a(i)+a(j): 1 <= j < i <= n}, where a(i) represents the previously defined terms of the sequence.
The definition of a(n) is the number of 2 X 2 matrices with entries mod n and nonzero determinant.

category: *combinatorial mathematics, discrete mathematics, polynomial and series expansions*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the number of 4 x 4 matrices with nonnegative integer entries where the sum of the entries in each row and each column is equal to n.

The definition of a(n) is generated by a sieve: keep the first number (0), drop every 2nd number, keep the new first number (1), drop every 3rd number, keep the new first number (3), drop every 4th number, and so on.
The definition of a(n) is: 2 together with the odd numbers (essentially the result of the first stage of the sieve of Eratosthenes), where the sequence starts at 1.

The definition of a(n) is: Start with a sequence of 1's, then replace every other 1 with a 2; then replace every third of the remaining 1's with a 3 and every third of the remaining 2's with a 3; then replace every fourth remaining 1, 2 or 3 with a 4; and so on. The limiting sequence is shown here.
The definition of a(n) is the number of distinct 3 X n binary matrices, considering permutations of both rows and columns.

The definition of a(n) is the number of partitional matroids on n elements, where a partitional matroid is a matroid that can be represented by a partition of the ground set into independent sets such that the union of any subfamily of these sets is also independent. The first few values of the sequence are 1, 2, 5, 16, 62, 276, 1377, 7596, 45789, 298626.
The definition of a(n) is the width (i.e., number of non-root vertices having degree 1) of the rooted tree associated with the Matula-Goebel number n.
The definition of a(n) is the depth of the rooted tree having the Matula-Goebel number n, a unique number that represents a rooted tree in a way based on the factorization of prime numbers.

The definition of a(n) is the maximal number of distinct rooted trees obtained from the rooted tree with Matula-Goebel number n by adding one pendant edge at one of its vertices. The Matula-Goebel number is a unique method by which each rooted tree can be associated with a single natural number, calculated using specific rules for prime factorizations related to the structural properties of the trees.

The definition of a(n) is the Matula number of the rooted tree obtained from the rooted tree T having Matula number n by replacing each edge of T with a path of length 2. The Matula number of any rooted tree is defined recursively: (1) The Matula number of a single-vertex tree is 1. (2) If T is a rooted tree and p is the smallest prime number such that T can be decomposed into subtrees T1, T2, ..., Tk (each of which is rooted at one of the children of the root of T), then the Matula number of T is the product of the p-th primes of the Matula numbers of T1, T2, ..., Tk.
The definition of a(n) is the number of independent subsets in the rooted tree, whose Matula-Goebel number is n, that include the root node.

The definition of a(n) is the first Zagreb index of the rooted tree with Matula-Goebel number n, a concept from mathematical chemistry that considers the sum of the squares of the vertex degrees. The Matula-Goebel number uniquely identifies rooted trees, enabling the computation of various tree invariants.

The definition of a(n) is the symmetry factor of the rooted tree with Matula-Goebel number n, where the Matula-Goebel number is a unique number assigned to each rooted tree based on its structure, such that different trees receive different numbers, and the symmetry factor represents the count of automorphisms (symmetries) of the tree.

The definition of a(n) is the Matula-Goebel number of the rooted tree obtained from the rooted tree with Matula-Goebel number n after removing the leaves, together with their incident edges. The Matula-Goebel number is a unique way of assigning a natural number to every rooted tree, defined using prime factorization and recursive structures.
The definition of a(n) is the diameter (i.e., largest distance between two vertices) of the rooted tree with Matula-Goebel number n, a unique number associated with the tree encoding its structure.

The definition of a(n) is the number of internal nodes in a rooted tree whose Matula-Goebel number is n. The Matula-Goebel number of a rooted tree is defined as follows: (1) The one-vertex tree is assigned the number 1; (2) If T1, T2,..., Tk are the branches of the root of tree T and their respective Matula-Goebel numbers are n1, n2,..., nk, then the Matula-Goebel number of T is the product of the primes with indices n1, n2,..., nk.

The definition of a(n) is the product, over all vertices v of the rooted tree with Matula-Goebel number n, of the number of vertices in the subtree with root v. The Matula-Goebel number is a unique encoding of a rooted tree defined as follows: 
1. The one-vertex tree is assigned the number 1.
2. If the tree T consists of the root connected to the roots of the trees T1, T2, ..., Tk, then the Matula-Goebel number of T is the product of the first k prime numbers, where the i-th prime number is the Matula-Goebel number of Ti.

The definition of a(n) is the number of ways to take apart the rooted tree corresponding to the Matula-Goebel number n by sequentially removing terminal edges. Each Matula-Goebel number uniquely represents a rooted tree and the process involves completely dismantling the tree by removing leaf edges one at a time until no edges remain.

The definition of a(n) is: Sum of the degrees of the nodes at level 1 in the rooted tree with Matula-Goebel number n. The Matula-Goebel number is a unique number assigned to a rooted tree and this number can be found using a specific prime factorization method.
The definition of a(n) is the number of labeled mobiles (circular rooted trees) with n nodes and k leaves.

category: *polynomial and series expansions, special numbers, group theory*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the sequence derived from the Molien series for the Weyl group E_7, commonly used in invariant theory and the study of symmetries in algebraic structures. The coefficients represent the degrees of the fundamental invariants.
The definition of a(n) is the multiplicative order of 3 modulo the nth positive integer m that is coprime with 3 (i.e., gcd(m, 3) = 1).
The definition of a(n) is: Periods of reciprocals of integers that are coprime with 10.
The definition of a(n) is the number of nonzero elements of multiplicative order k in the Galois field GF(2^n) where k ranges from 1 to 2^n-1 (n >= 1).
The definition of a(n) is: Numbers m for which there exist d(1),...,d(m), each in {0,1}, such that the sum of d(i)*d(i+k) over all i from 1 to m-k is odd for all k from 0 to m-1.
The definition of a(n) is the number of distinct letters in the (American) English name of the number n (for example, "one" for 1 and "two" for 2), excluding spaces and hyphens.
The definition of a(n) is: Positive integers with English names ending in "x".

The definition of a(n) is the number of series-parallel networks with n unlabeled edges, where a series-parallel network is a two-terminal graph that can be constructed from a single edge by recursively applying two operations: series composition and parallel composition. These networks are also referred to as yoke-chains by Cayley and MacMahon.
The definition of a(n) is numbers n such that n^2 - n is divisible by 24.
The definition of a(n) is: Horizontal para-Fibonacci sequence: indicates which column of the Wythoff array (starting column count at 1) contains n.

category: *combinatorial mathematics, special numbers, polynomial and series expansions*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the partial sums of the Catalan numbers starting from C1, C2, C3, ..., where Cn is the nth Catalan number. These sums begin with 1, 3, 8, 22, ...
The definition of a(n) is the number of iterations required to reduce a number n to a single digit by multiplying its digits together.
The definition of a(n) is the number of partitions of n in which the order of the parts is strictly increasing and no two parts differ by more than 1.

category: *graph theory, discrete mathematics, geometry and topology*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the number of rooted polyhedral graphs with n edges, where a polyhedral graph is a graph that can be embedded on the surface of a sphere such that all its faces (including the unbounded one if consider planar graph) are bounded by simple cycles.

category: *combinatorial mathematics, geometry and topology, discrete mathematics*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is: Place n equally-spaced points around a circle and join every pair of points by a chord; this divides the circle into a(n) regions. In mathematical context, this refers to the maximum number of regions into which the circle is divided by the chords.

category: *combinatorial mathematics, geometry and topology, discrete mathematics*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the number of intersections of diagonals in the interior of a regular n-gon, where no three diagonals are concurrent, and intersections are counted only if they occur strictly inside the polygon.

category: *combinatorial mathematics, geometry and topology, polynomial and series expansions*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the maximal number of regions obtained by joining n points around a circle by straight lines. Additionally, it represents the number of regions in 4-dimensional space formed by n-1 hyperplanes.

category: *combinatorial mathematics, geometry and topology, discrete mathematics*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the number of intersection points formed inside a regular n-gon when all diagonals are drawn. Note that these intersection points exclude the vertices of the n-gon itself and are counted specifically when two or more diagonals intersect within the interior.
The definition of a(n) is primes whose base-2 representation is also the base-3 representation of a prime, considering base-2 and base-3 representations as whole numbers without leading zeroes.
The definition of a(n) is primes that when written in base 4, then reinterpreted in base 10, again give primes.
The definition of a(n) is the numbers k such that the difference between the k-th prime and the next prime is 100.
The definition of a(n) is primes such that the next prime is 4 greater than the prime itself.
The definition of a(n) is primes p such that p + 4 is also prime.
The definition of a(n) is the smallest prime p such that there is a gap of 2n between p and the previous prime.
The definition of a(n) is numbers n such that the n-th and the (n+1)-st primes are twin primes (two prime numbers that differ by 2).
The definition of a(n) is the lower prime of a pair of consecutive primes whose difference is exactly 14.
The definition of a(n) is the lower prime of a difference of 10 between consecutive primes.
The definition of a(n) is numbers k such that the difference between the k-th prime and the (k+1)-th prime is exactly 4.
The definition of a(n) is the n-th prime number p such that q - p = 36, where q is the next prime after p.
The definition of a(n) is the smallest k such that prime(n)*k+1 is prime.
The definition of a(n) is the smallest prime number that is congruent to 1 modulo the n-th prime number in the sequence of all prime numbers.
The definition of a(n) is the initial prime in a set of at least 4 consecutive prime numbers in an arithmetic progression with a common difference of 30.
The definition of a(n) is the least odd number k such that k * 2^n + 1 is a prime number.
The definition of a(n) is the sequence of consecutive internal states generated by the IMSL pseudo-random number generator RNUN when it is initialized with the seed ISEED=1.

The definition of a(n) is: Consecutive internal states of the second of the two linear congruential random number generators whose combined output is used in function RANDOM_NUMBER in version 8 of the Intel FORTRAN Compiler for Linux, using its intrinsic initialization.

The definition of a(n) is: Consecutive internal states of a linear congruential pseudo-random number generator with the multiplier parameter 69069, which was proposed by George Marsaglia as a "candidate for the best of all multipliers".
The definition of a(n) is consecutive states of the linear congruential pseudo-random number generator used in the function rand() in the Standard C library (VAX C) when started at 1.

The definition of a(n) is the consecutive internal states of the linear congruential pseudo-random number generator RANDU that was used in the IBM Scientific Subroutine Library for IBM System/360 computers in the 1970s, seeded with a specific initial value and using the parameters set by IBM.

The definition of a(n) is the sequence of consecutive states of a linear congruential pseudo-random number generator with initial seed a(0) = 1, and using the multiplier that is the spectrally best primitive root modulo 2^31-1.

category: *combinatorial mathematics, discrete mathematics, geometry and topology*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the number of possible queen moves on an n X n chessboard, considering all positions where a queen can move horizontally, vertically, or diagonally across the board.

category: *combinatorial mathematics, discrete mathematics, geometry and topology*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is: Maximal number of non-attacking queens that can be placed on an n x n right triangular chessboard, where each side of the triangle has n cells.
The definition of a(n) is the number of ways to place 3 nonattacking queens on an n X n chessboard, where queens can attack any square on the same row, column, or diagonal.

The definition of a(n) is: RATS: Reverse Add Then Sort the digits applied to previous term, starting with 1. Note: "RATS" is a specific transformation where one takes the previous term, reverses its digits, adds this to the original term, and then sorts the resulting digits in ascending order.
The definition of a(n) is RATS(n): Reverse Add Then Sort the digits of the number obtained by the previous step.
The definition of a(n) is the trajectory of the binary number 10110 under the operation 'Reverse and Add!' carried out in base 2.
The definition of a(n) is a sequence where each term is obtained by reversing the digits of the previous term and adding it to the previous term, starting with 196.
The definition of a(n) is: A self-generating sequence where the number of 3's between any two successive 2's is denoted by a(n).

The definition of a(n) is a self-generating sequence where each term depends on particular previously occurred values (see Comments for detailed definition and examples about the construction of the sequence).

category: *polynomial and series expansions, special numbers, discrete mathematics*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the expansion of (8 + 7 x - 7 x^2 - 7 x^3)/(1 - 6 x - 7 x^2 + 5 x^3 + 6 x^4).
The definition of a(n) is "Fermi-Dirac primes": numbers of the form p^(2^k) where p is a prime number and k is a non-negative integer.

The definition of a(n) is the number of digits in the concatenation of the first n prime numbers. Prime numbers are natural numbers greater than 1 that have no positive divisors other than 1 and itself.

The definition of a(n) is the sequence of integers representing the first column of the spectral array W(sqrt(2)), which arises in the study of the spectral properties of recurrent sequences connected to quadratic irrationalities.

category: *discrete mathematics, combinatorial mathematics, geometry and topology*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is: Write 1, 2, ... in a clockwise spiral; sequence gives numbers on positive x axis. This spiral starts at the origin (0,0) and the positive x axis corresponds to the positions (0,1), (0,2), (0,3), and so on.

category: *combinatorial mathematics, discrete mathematics, polynomial and series expansions*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the number of ways to tile a 6 X n rectangle using 1 X 1 and 2 X 2 tiles.

category: *geometry and topology, combinatorial mathematics, special numbers*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is a(2n) and a(2n+1) are side lengths of a Beentjes sequence of perfect squared rectangles, starting with a 33 X 32 rectangle.

category: *geometry and topology, discrete mathematics, combinatorial mathematics*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the number of toothpicks present after n stages of a process where toothpicks are continuously added according to specific geometric rules, starting with a single toothpick.
The definition of a(n) is the number of triples (i, j, k) such that 1 <= i <= j < k <= n and the greatest common divisor (gcd) of {i, j, k} is 1.
The definition of a(n) is the number of ordered triples (a, b, c) such that the greatest common divisor (gcd) of a, b, and c is 1, where a, b, and c are integers with 1 <= a, b, c <= n.

category: *polynomial and series expansions, special numbers, group theory*
problem_statement: The definition of a(n) is the q-expansion coefficients of the character of the vertex-operator superalgebra of rank 23.5, on which the Baby Monster group acts.
The definition of a(n) is the number of ways to partition n into distinct squares, where each partition must consist of unique square numbers.
The definition of a(n) is the u-pile count for the 4-Wythoff game with i=2, where players alternately remove 1 or 2 tokens from a pile and the game starts with 4 piles.

The definition of a(n) is: Horizontal para-Fibonacci sequence: says which column of Wythoff array (starting column count at 0) contains n+1. The Wythoff array is derived from the Wythoff pairs, which are ordered pairs of non-negative integers generated by the golden ratio.
The definition of a(n) is the smallest term in the Zeckendorf representation of n, where each positive integer is represented as the sum of one or more distinct, non-consecutive Fibonacci numbers.
The definition of a(n) is the number of terms in the Zeckendorf representation of n, where n is expressed as a sum of non-consecutive distinct Fibonacci numbers.
